questions.prompt: The last line of this poem repeats words like "pleasing" and "prince" from its first line.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this poem in which a man loses the title object and dreams that it is reborn as a woman on the far bank of a stream.

B.question: The anonymous Pearl Poet is also thought to have written this poem, whose title characters are a member of King Arthur's Round Table and the spirit who ensnares him in a "beheading game."
B.answer: Sir Gawain and the Green Knight

C.question: The Pearl Poet may have also written this 14th-century poem, in which a corpse found underneath St. Paul's Cathedral tells its life story to the title bishop.

questions.prompt: This theorist coined the term "holding environment" to describe the role of the therapeutic setting.  For 10 points each-

A.question: What pioneering object-relations theorist posited the "true and false self" and the "transitional object"?
A.answer: D. W. Winnicott (or Donald Woods Winnicott)

B.question: Winnicott wrote a book titled for this behavior "and reality." The "deep" form of this usually recreational activity titles a Clifford Geertz essay on cockfighting.
B.answer: play(ing) (accept answers indicating playing games; accept Playing and Reality or Deep Play: Notes on the Balinese Cockfight)

C.question: Winnicott argued that the "ego-relatedness" stage enables the development of this capacity, which is crucial to avoid "false life."  Paradoxically, this abi lity develops in the "presence of the mother."
C.answer: capacity to be alone (or solitude; or be by one's self; prompt on "independence"; do not accept or prompt on "loneliness")

questions.prompt: In this film, Max's wife Kim notices that the protagonist is wearing the same fancy bracelet that Max bought for her.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this 2020 comedy by Emma Seligman about a young Jewish woman named Danielle attending an event honoring a recently deceased relative.

B.question: Danielle's father is played by actor Fred Melamed, perhaps best known for portraying Sy Ableman, the title character of this 2009 film set in St. Louis Park, Minnesota.

C.question: Seligman has cited these directors of A Serious Man and Inside Llewyn Davis as an influence on Shiva Baby.
C.answer: Coen brothers (or Coens; or Joel and Ethan Coen)

questions.prompt: A character in this story commits suicide with pills and sherry after discovering that her lover has taken Madge to a restaurant.  For 10 points each-

A.question: Name this short story that begins "John and Mary meet-what happens next?" and imagines six possible outcomes.

B.question: "Happy Endings" is by this Canadian author of The Handmaid's Tale.

C.question: This Atwood novel cuts between Iris Chase Griffen's present life, her past life, and the title novel -within-a-novel, which is credited to her sister Laura.

questions.prompt: This criterion is superseded by the Ledoux [leh-DOO] criterion in the presence of composition gradients.  For 10 points each-

A.question: Name this criterion that predicts instability when the temperature gradient in a stratified fluid is super-adiabatic [AY-dee-uh-BAT-ik].

B.question: In terms of the gravitational constant G, speed of light c, and mass M, what is the Schwarzschild radius for a black hole of mass M?

C.question: The Schwarzschild telescope eliminates both coma and this other aberration that distorts images made by mirrors with a namesake shape.

questions.prompt: This artist's study drawings include a 72-faced polyhedron studded with diamond peaks.  For 10 points each -

A.question: What artist made a 15th-century drawing of a chalice that looks strikingly like a wireframe image used in modern 3D modeling?

B.question: Uccello's wireframe chalice was a study for this drafting technique that depends on a vanishing point.
B.answer: linear perspective (or point-projection perspective; accept one-point perspective)

C.question: Uccello also made a wireframe study of a mazzocchio [mah-ZOH-kee-oh], a doughnut-shaped type of headgear shown in his Life of Noah frescoes in the Green Cloister of this church that also contains Masaccio's The Holy Trinity.

questions.prompt: A portrait composed by this man shows his bearded assistant, Marcus Sparling, sitting aboard the "Photographic Van."  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this pioneer of British war photography, who founded the Photographic Society after  the Great Exhibition of 1851.

B.question: Fenton and James Robertson photographed the siege of Sevastopol during this war.

C.question: Two versions of Fenton's photo Valley of the Shadow of Death differ in the placement of these discarded items: either in the path of a dirt road, or lying in the adjacent ditch.
C.answer: cannon balls (or round shot or solid shot; do not accept or prompt on "cannon")

questions.prompt: Ali Smith's novel Girl Meets Boy is inspired by the myth of this character, whose poor parents Ligdus and Telethusa could not afford a dowry.  For 10 p oints each-

A.question: Name this character who is born a girl, raised as a boy, and then prays to the gods to be transformed into a man before marrying Ianthe [EE-ann-thay].

B.question: This Egyptian goddess responds to Iphis's prayers.  The syncretic deity Serapis [sih-RAY-pis] often replaced Osiris as her consort in Greco-Roman cults.

C.question: This Lapith woman was also transformed into a man, and given impenetrabl e skin, after being raped by Poseidon.

questions.prompt: Gary Martin's "methods manual" for this discipline uses Brent Berlin's classification of uses of Rapanea by the Tzeltal people as an example.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Mark Plotkin is a scholar within what interdisciplinary field that fuses biology and social science?

B.question: Plotkin's wrote a book of "tales" of apprenticeship to one of these religious men who visit the spirit world in an altered state of consciousness.
B.answer: shamans (accept Tales of a Shaman's Apprentice)

C.question: This Peruvian-American author discussed training with a Yaqui [YAH-kee] shaman in his 1968 book The Teachings of Don Juan.

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about dynamical systems:

A.question: This is the collection of points generated by applying a system's evolution function to a starting point.  This term is also used for the path of an astronomical body through space.

B.question: Conservative systems obey this Frenchman's recurrence theorem.  He lends his name to a "map" that plots the points where periodic orbits first intersect a section transverse to the system's flow.
B.answer: Henri Poincaré (accept Poincaré recurrence theorem or Poincaré map(s) or Poincaré section(s))

C.question: This type of orbit connects a saddle point to itself.  Its "hetero" counterpart connects different fixed points.

questions.prompt: This U.S. ambassador facilitated a meeting in which Félix Díaz [FAY-leeks DEE-ahz] allied with a general to carry out a military coup [koo].  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this ambassador who was recalled shortly after he helped to arrange the "Pact of the Embassy" during the Ten Tragic Days.

B.question: Díaz and Victoriano Huerta [veek-tor-ee-AH-noh "WARE"-tah] overthrew this democratically elected Mexican president, who had earlier led the 1910 revolution that ended the Porfiriato [por-feer-ee-AH-toh].
B.answer: Francisco Madero [mah-"DARE"-oh] (or Francisco Ignacio Madero González or Francisco Ygnacio Madero González; accept Francisco Indalecio Madero González) [The Porfiriato was named after the dictator Porfirio Díaz, who was the uncle of Félix Díaz.]

C.question: A soldadera ["sole"-dah-"DARE"-ah] who fought for Francisco Madero may have inspired this popular revolutionary ballad about a woman who follows a military regiment "madly in love with the sergeant."

questions.prompt: The first "journal" of this type of music notes "I have a 'Symphony of noises' in mind; after all, there has been a symphony of psalms."  For 10 poin ts each-

A.question: Pierre Schaeffer's Cinq études de bruits [SAHNK ay-TOOD day broo-EE] are what type of music that involves the recording and manipulation of sounds on a medium like tape?
A.answer: musique concrète ["music" kohn-KRET] (or concrete music; do not accept or prompt on "musique électronique" or "electronic music")

B.question: Schaeffer's musique concrète works include a symphony for this number of people, the number of channels in a monophonic recording.
B.answer: 1 (or solo; accept Symphonie pour un homme seul or Symphony for One Man Alone)

C.question: This composer applied musique concrète techniques to a recording of a boy soprano in his Gesang der Jünglinge [geh-ZAHNG dair YOONG-ling-geh].  His 1957 compositon Gruppen [GROO-pen] calls for for three orchestras.

questions.prompt: The cabin in which one of these poems was written includes a plaque with the lines "over all of the hills / peace comes anew."  For 10 points each -

A.question: Give this title of two German romantic poems, one of which was supposedly written under an oak.

B.question: Those two poems titled "Wanderer's Nightsong" were written by this German author of the novel The Sorrows of Young Werther.

C.question: The line "tell, you stones, O speak, you towering palaces" opens the first entry in this cycle of 24 poems, which Goethe wrote about a journey abroad.
C.answer: Roman Elegies (or Erotica Romana; or Romische Elegien)

questions.prompt: Charlotte von Kirschbaum [shar-LOH-teh von KEERSH-baum] contributed significant amounts of this text, which rejects the idea of an abstract decree in its approach to the doctrine of election.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this unfinished, four-volume magnum opus of Swiss theologian Karl Barth ["bart"].

B.question: Barth pioneered dialectical theology with a commentary on this long Pauline epistle addressed to churches in  an Italian city.
B.answer: Epistle to the Romans (or Letter to the Romans)

C.question: In 1934 Barth wrote the essay Nein! in response to Emil Brunner, who had implicated Barth in an attempt to combine neo-orthodoxy with this extra-biblical argument for God.

questions.prompt: This scientist co-developed the CLARITY technique, which uses hydrogels to render brain tissue transparent.  For 10 points each-

A.question: Name this scientist whose lab at Stanford published a 2005 paper describing the use of a protein from green algae called ChR2 to precisely create depolarization-mediated currents.

B.question: Karl Deisseroth's work formed the basis for this field, which designs systems to mani pulate the activity of neurons using light.

C.question: ChR2 is an example of the "channel" type of these proteins.  In the eye, these proteins are activated by isomerization ["eye"-SAH-muh-ruh-ZAY-shun] of retinal [RET-in-al] to convert incoming photons to neural signals.

questions.prompt: For 10 points each-answer the following about epithets referring to thunderbolts in military history:

A.question: The twelfth of these largest units in the Imperial Roman Army was nicknamed fulminata ["fool-me"-NAH-tah] or "thunderbolt" for the insignia on its shields.  These units contained 3,000 to 6,000 men.
A.answer: legions (or legio; accept Legio XII Fulminata)

B.question: This Ottoman sultan was nicknamed "the Thunderbolt" after crushing a crusader army at the Battle of Nicopolis [nik-AH-puh-liss].

C.question: A man of this name known as Keraunos [keh-RAU-nohs], or "thunderbolt," seized the throne of Macedonia after the Battle of Corupedium [kuh-rup-EE-dee-um] and murdered Seleucus [suh-LOO-kus] Nicator.
C.answer: Ptolemy (or Ptolemaeus or Ptolemaios; accept Ptolemy Keraunos)

questions.prompt: Warren Upham's two enduring publications are an encyclopedia of Minnesota geographic place names and a monograph that gave this body of water its name.  For 10 points each -

A.question: What glacial lake drained south through the Traverse Gap into Glacial River Warren?

B.question: Louis Agassiz is the namesake of a glacier this state's Glacier National Park.

C.question: Agassiz is the namesake of a mountain that, from Flagstaff, blocks the view of this tallest mountain i n Arizona.
C.answer: Humphreys Peak (or Aaloosaktukwi or Dook'o'oosliid; prompt on "Humphreys")

questions.prompt: For functions f and g of variables p and q, this operation equals "df/dp dg/dq" ["D-F D-P times D-G D-Q"], minus "df/dq dg/dp" ["D-F D-Q times D-G D-P"].  For 10 points each -

A.question: Identify this operation named for a French physicist.

B.question: A variable A is a constant of motion if dA/dt ["D-A D-T"] equals the Poisson bracket of A with this quantity.  It represents the total energy of a system.

C.question: Paul Dirac introduced these constraints, whose Poisson bracket with all other constraints vanishes in a Hamiltonian system.  They are distinct from primary and secondary constraints.

questions.prompt: A man with this surname ordered the fortification of Bunker Hill.  For 10 points each -

A.question: Give this surname of Artemas, a major-general who was made second-in-command of the Continental Army in 1776.

B.question: Another man surnamed Ward, Aaron Montgomery Ward, founded a dry goods store that became one of the first of these large retailers in the U.S. and competed with Macy's and Marshall Field.

C.question: A different Ward, Ward McAllister, popularized the notion that this many people comprised New York's high society in the Gilded Age, although McAllister's actual list contained only 150.

questions.prompt: In 2010 the men's basketball team from this school won its only Big East Tourna ment championship.  For 10 points each-

A.question: Name this school, which lost in the Final Four of that year's NCAA tournament to eventual champion Duke in a game that its star Da'Sean Butler left due to a knee injury.  Jevon Carter [jeh-VAHN "carter"] later played for this school.

B.question: That West Virginia team was coached by this man, who has coached at the school since 2007.

C.question: West Virginia advanced to that Final Four with an Elite Eight upset of this top -seeded team, which was led by point guard John Wall and coach John Calipari.

questions.prompt: Chicago gangs are the subject of this man's first novel, Diversey [dih-VER-see].  For 10 points each -

A.question: Name this 20th-century American author whose novels include Long Remember and Spirit Lake, as well as one in which William Collins leads the "Raiders."
A.answer: (Benjamin) MacKinlay Kantor [William Collins appears in Andersonville.]

B.question: Kantor wrote a 1961 book titled for this historical counterfactual.  Time -traveling South Africans supply AK-47s that prove decisive in this outcome in a 1992 novel.
B.answer: Confederacy winning the Civil War (accept answers indicating South or Confederacy or Confederate States or CSA winning the U.S. Civil War; accept If the South Had Won the War) [The second sentence refers to Harry Turtledove's The Guns of the South.]

C.question: Kantor's novel Glory for Me was adapted for the screen as The Best Years of Our Lives by this playwright, whose own works include Idiot's Delight and The Petrified Forest.

questions.prompt: Greece protested a treaty between Turkey and this country that would have established an exclusive economic zone.  For 10 points each -

A.question: A "Government of National Accord" created after a 2011 NATO intervention signed that treaty on behalf of what North African country?

B.question: Turkey defended the treaty via this state-run news agency that, like state broadcaster TRT, is a mouthpiece for the ruling AKP.
B.answer: Anadolu Agency (or Anadolu Ajansi; prompt on "AA" or "Anatolian (Agency)")

C.question: In 2021 the deal was voided in Libya as incompatible with the United Nations convention that establishes a legal framework for maritime activities, which is almost always known by this six -letter acronym.
C.answer: UNCLOS [UNN-klahss or "U-N-C-L-O-S"] (accept UNCLOS III) [which stands for "United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea."]

questions.prompt: These lifeforms are made from skin and cardiac muscle cells and designed using evolutionary algorithms.  For 10 points each-

A.question: Name these synthetic lifeforms developed in 2020 by a team including Sam Kriegman and Douglas Blackiston.

B.question: The first xenobots were created using cells from Xenopus laevis [ZEN-uh-puss LAY-viss], the "African clawed" species of this animal.
B.answer: African clawed frog(s) (accept African clawed toad(s))

C.question: This two-word phrase refers to the way that the xenobots were designed via computer simulation.  This phrase is modeled on similar phrases like in vivo and in vitro.
